author: By Travis Diehl
title: In Brutal Ordeals, a Performance Artist Embodies the Oppressed
description: It’s hard to look away from Carlos Martiel’s feats of endurance and self-harm. Does his sacrifice help us understand a legacy of racist violence?
content: Confronting you head-on are a hanging flag, and a man in danger of hanging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Fallout From Cyberattack at Ascension Hospitals Persists, Causing Delays in Patient Care
description: For two weeks at the 140-hospital system, doctors and nurses have had little access to digital records for patient histories, resorting to paper and faxes to treat people.
content: In more than a dozen states, doctors and nurses have resorted to paper and handwritten treatment orders to chart patient illnesses and track them, unable to access the detailed medical histories that have long been available only through computerized records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: What’s in Your Hurricane Stash?
description: The hurricane season begins on June 1. We want to know how you prepare.
content: Growing up in Miami, the hurricane stash lived in the back of my mom’s bedroom year-round: bottles of water, buy-one-get-one-free Publix deals on cans of tuna fish, kidney and black beans, popcorn, crackers, an assortment of flashlights and a radio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel Pushes Deeper Into Rafah, Defying International Opinion
description: While the government has been hit with a string of diplomatic and legal defeats, the Israeli public’s support for the Gaza war remains strong.
content: Israel’s military battled deeper into Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Thursday, expanding its offensive into the city and driving more people out of it, while Israel faced growing international pressure and isolation over its war against Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: America Is Still Having a ‘Vibecession’
description: Most voters say that they’re doing OK but that the economy is bad.
content: If Donald Trump wins the election, the main reason will surely be that a majority of voters believe that America’s economy is in bad shape. And no matter how much you may dread a second Trump administration, electoral defeat for an incumbent who is seen as presiding over a bad economy is, at least in one sense, politics as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: The ‘Trump-Oprah’ Voter
description: Many Americans think of Donald Trump as a celebrity first and a politician second, no matter his record or offenses.
content: There is one question about Donald Trump that I’m asked above all others, as someone whose professional life is devoted to studying voter behavior and, in particular, what drives Republicans. Here is a man who remains the front-runner for the presidency despite facing dozens of felony charges, a jury verdict as soon as next week, and the lingering frustration of voters — including Republicans — over the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol. Why doesn’t any of it affect his standing in the polls?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: F.D.A. Panel Endorses Safety of Colon-Cancer Blood Test
description: The Guardant Health Shield test, one committee member said, “is better than nothing for patients who are getting nothing, but it is not better than a colonoscopy.”
content: A committee of experts that advises the Food and Drug Administration voted by large majorities on Thursday that a new blood test to screen people for colon and rectal cancers was safe and effective, and that its benefits outweighed its risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sunak Says U.K. Won’t Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda Before Election
description: The prime minister’s admission that a key political project will not begin before voters head to the polls puts the Conservatives in a risky position.
content: In calling a general election, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain cast himself this week as a leader with a clear plan. That did not include carrying an umbrella during his remarks in front of 10 Downing Street, where Mr. Sunak was drenched in a spring shower that yielded a flood of snarky headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Austin Walsh
title: Do You Want a ‘Unified Reich’ Mind-Set in the White House?
description: Young Republican staff members appear to be developing terminal white nationalist brain. And they will staff the next Republican administration.
content: It is hard to be shocked by Donald Trump anymore. The former president’s trial over hush money paid to a porn star has made history, and his performance in court has been so farcical that Mr. Trump was threatened with jail time for contempt of court. He has called his political enemies “vermin” and said that immigrants are “poisoning the blood” of America. Mr. Trump’s transgressions against American political norms are by now almost a cliché.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Bintliff
title: U.K. 2024 General Election: What to Know
description: The governing Conservative Party could be voted out of power for the first time in 14 years.
content: The general election on July 4 is a pivotal moment for Britain after 14 years of government by the Conservative Party. The last full parliamentary election was in December 2019, when Boris Johnson won a landslide victory for the Conservatives, propelled by his charisma and a promise to “Get Brexit done” after the country’s decision to leave the European Union in a 2016 referendum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe, Grace Whitaker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: At U.C.L.A., Protesters Briefly Form Encampment and Occupy Building Before Police Move In
description: The actions came as the university chancellor testified before Congress. The university said that it was not aware of the police making any arrests.
content: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators at the University of California, Los Angeles, briefly formed a new encampment and then took over a campus building on Thursday before police officers in riot gear moved in to disband the efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Far-Right E.U. Lawmakers Remove Germany’s AfD Party Before Elections
description: The exclusion is a sign that domestic troubles for the Alternative for Germany party are starting to spill into European Union politics before elections.
content: A far-right group in the European Union’s Parliament announced on Thursday that it had ousted the Alternative for Germany party from its coalition, dealing a severe blow to a key alliance just two weeks before E.U. parliamentary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia Detains Another Defense Official, in New Sign of Putin Shake-Up
description: Lt. Gen. Vadim Shamarin is accused of “large-scale” bribery, the latest in a series of high-profile arrests that have coincided with the appointment of a new defense minister.
content: Russia has jailed a top defense official, the fourth in a month, expanding President Vladimir V. Putin’s biggest shake-up of his military leadership since the invasion of Ukraine more than two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Houses Up, Condos Down. What’s Selling in the Hamptons These Days?

content: During the first quarter of 2024, sales of single-family homes in the Hamptons were up 35 percent year-over-year, and sale prices for those homes increased more than 25 percent, according to data from the Elliman Report. What’s driving these increases?

title: Baltimore’s Unprecedented Overdose Crisis: 5 Takeaways

content: Baltimore has become the epicenter of the worst drug crisis ever seen in a major American city, an examination by The New York Times and The Baltimore Banner has found. The city’s death rate from 2018 to 2022 was nearly double that of any other large city — a fact not known by several top leaders, including the mayor and the deputy mayor, who used to lead the city’s Health Department.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Israel took several tough diplomatic blows over the past week, some of which had been feared for years. Yet the rising outcry against Israel abroad appears not to have swayed the Israeli public, whose views on the country’s military campaign in Gaza are largely different from those of the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

content: On Mother’s Day in the main hall of the Ridgewood Presbyterian Church in Queens, a handful of members of Gamelan Dharma Swara, an ensemble that plays traditional and contemporary Balinese music, practiced its new piece, “Pagar Ayu.” It was a joyous cacophony — a melding of metallophones, other percussive instruments and flute — though it was still in need of refinement.

Sophia Meneve, Sotheby’s International Realty, 201-394-7170; sothebysrealty.com

title: U.S. Calls for Breakup of Ticketmaster Owner

content: The Justice Department and a group of states plan to sue Live Nation Entertainment, the concert giant that owns Ticketmaster, as soon as Thursday, accusing it of illegally maintaining a monopoly in the live entertainment industry, said three people familiar with the matter.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Nikki Haley, Ever Pragmatic, Tries to Keep Her Options Open

Eight years ago, she basically did the same thing: She was critical of him before he got the nomination, then once he did, said she’d vote for him and sort of faded into the background, before her surprise arrival in the administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Elisa Gutierrez, Anna Foley and Sophia Lanman
title: Why Joe Biden Isn’t Getting Credit for the Economy
description: To the people he needs to win over, prices still feel too high and wages too low.
content: As he runs for re-election, President Biden is talking about one specific issue a lot: the economy. He emphasizes the nation’s low unemployment and slowing inflation, and even rolled out a catchy nickname for the good numbers: Bidenomics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Zhu, Nick Thieme and Jessica Gallagher
title: Almost 6,000 Dead in 6 Years: How Baltimore Became the U.S. Overdose Capital
description: The city was once hailed for its response to addiction. But as fentanyl flooded the streets and officials shifted priorities, deaths hit unprecedented heights.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Shwayder, Jenna Russell and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Students Walk Out in Protest at Harvard Commencement
description: Anger at the university’s decision to bar 13 seniors from the ceremony in the wake of campus demonstrations over the war in Gaza was a flashpoint for the protest on Thursday.

title: Some iPhone Customers Could Get Up to $349 in an Apple Settlement
description: A class-action lawsuit about audio issues in iPhone 7 and 7 Plus phones has led to a $35 million settlement, though the company denies the phones were faulty.

title: Joy for a Migrant Family With a Wedding in the Park
description: A couple from Ecuador were married with the help of a nonprofit that aids migrants. They were joined by their 7-year-old son.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll meet a couple who arrived in New York City as migrants from Ecuador a couple of months ago — and were married on Wednesday. We’ll also find out why a beach that has been closed on Sunday mornings since shortly after the Civil War is now opening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Graduation’s Pomp Goes On, No Matter the Circumstance
description: Commencement is the rare American ritual that still has rules. That’s why it’s ripe for disruption.
content: Recycled robes, processional marches, silver pens from Tiffany: It is graduation season in America. May brings a nationwide festival of youth, with roots stretching back to before the foundation of the republic, and though many college commencements this month have taken place under police surveillance amid student outcry, the ceremonies have gone on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman
title: Pro-Palestinian Activism Marks CUNY Law Graduation Despite Speaker Ban
description: With speeches canceled, students at the CUNY School of Law ceremony chanted, carried signs and walked out.
content: In some ways, a walkout by pro-Palestinian students at the City University of New York School of Law’s commencement on Thursday was part of the unique political moment that has marked the Class of 2024’s graduation season at so many universities.
source.name: The New York Times

Trump.

content: Former President Donald J. Trump relentlessly criticized the Federal Reserve and Jerome H. Powell, its chair, during his time in office. source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Amtrak Is to Blame for a Hellish Night for New Jersey Commuters
description: Sharing tracks means that any disruption along the 427-mile Northeast Corridor, which links Boston to Washington, D.C., can be felt by thousands of passengers.
content: At 5:05 p.m. on Wednesday, just as the evening rush hour picked up steam, an overhead wire that transmits traffic signals fell and struck a cable that provides electrical power to trains on Amtrak’s Northeast Corridor in Kearny, N.J., a few miles west of New York City.

content: This week, Karim Khan, the top prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, requested arrest warrants for Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the country’s defense minister, Yoav Gallant.

description: The railroad company reached an agreement with the federal government to settle claims and costs from the 2023 derailment of a train carrying hazardous materials in the Ohio town.
content: Norfolk Southern has agreed to pay more than $310 million to settle claims and cover costs stemming from the February 2023 derailment of a freight train carrying hazardous materials in an Ohio town, the federal government said on Thursday.

title: Bob McCreadie, ‘the Master of Going Faster,’ Dies at 73

content: Bob McCreadie, who was one of the winningest drivers in dirt racing history and was regularly introduced by announcers as “the master of going faster,” died on May 15 at his home in Watertown, N.Y. He was 73.

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Hit Man’ Review: It’s a Hit, Man
description: Glen Powell stars in one of the year’s funniest, sexiest, most enjoyable movies — and somehow it’s surprisingly deep, too.
content: If I see a movie more delightful than “Hit Man” this year, I’ll be surprised. It’s the kind of romp people are talking about when they say that “they don’t make them like they used to”: It’s romantic, sexy, hilarious, satisfying and a genuine star-clinching turn for Glen Powell, who’s been having a moment for about two years now. It’s got the cheeky verve of a 1940s screwball rom-com in a thoroughly contemporary (and slightly racier) package. I’ve seen it twice, and a huge grin plastered itself across my face both times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Elise Stefanik Has Gained Widespread Attention in Antisemitism Hearings
description: The Republican of New York was already a rising star within her party before the Israel-Hamas war turbocharged concerns about antisemitic incidents in American education.
content: Representative Elise Stefanik of New York may not be a committee chair, but perhaps no single Republican lawmaker has more forcefully clashed with elite university leaders over how they are handling antisemitism on campus.

author: By Gisela Williams
title: A Mediterranean-Inspired Getaway in an Australian Surf Town
description: Plus: golden handbags, a Brooklyn boutique’s Tokyo pop-up and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: The origins of Il Delfino, a new oceanside inn in the surf town of Yamba on Australia’s east coast, go back to its founder’s childhood. “I grew up in this area, fascinated by this ramshackle surf cottage,” says the Australian fashion stylist Sheree Commerford. “Having it was a secret dream for as long as I can remember.” At the end of 2021, Commerford bought the building, which had previously been a rustic family lodge, and spent the last two years transforming it into a four-room inn and bungalow that she opened last month. “We wanted to keep all its original midcentury features but add inspiration from some of my favorite travels in the Mediterranean,” she says. That means whitewashed walls, citrus trees in terra-cotta pots and a terrace with Italian-made sun beds and uninterrupted ocean views. The guest rooms, which are named for Italian destinations like Ravello and Ischia, are all equipped with kitchens and each feature a colorful mural by the Australian artist Heidi Middleton. There’s no restaurant at the hotel, but staff will organize breakfast boxes upon request and recommend places to eat in Yamba. They can also help arrange whale-watching excursions, in-house massages and surf lessons. From about $300 with a two-night minimum, ildelfino.com.au.

title: Nigel Farage to Skip U.K. Election So He Can Focus on Helping Trump
description: The populist British politician, a driving force behind Brexit, said he would not run in the July general election, citing the global importance of the American campaign.
content: Nigel Farage, the broadcaster and populist politician who championed Brexit, said on Thursday that he would not run for a seat in the British Parliament in a general election on July 4, preferring to focus on helping former President Donald J. Trump recapture the White House in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Cassie After Sean Combs Footage: ‘Open Your Heart to Believing Victims’
description: The singer, who sued the hip-hop mogul over allegations of rape and abuse, posted a statement after 2016 video emerged last week showing him assaulting her in a hotel.
content: Cassie, the singer who accused Sean Combs of years of physical and sexual abuse in a lawsuit that she settled, on Thursday addressed footage of the music mogul assaulting her that emerged last week, saying in an Instagram post that domestic violence had broken her down to “someone I never thought I would become.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: When Representation Forgets to Include the Jews
description: The motion picture academy’s museum finally acknowledges the industry’s debt.
content: The Jews who founded Hollywood — and make no mistake, the big studio heads were overwhelmingly Jewish — shared several things: ambition, creative vision and killer business instincts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Warns Israel Against Cutting Off Palestinian Banks
description: The Treasury secretary said allies from the Group of 7 nations must work to stabilize the West Bank economy and increase Gaza aid.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned Israel on Thursday against cutting off ties between Palestinian and Israeli banks, arguing that such a move would further destabilize the economy of the West Bank when Palestinians were already facing dire economic conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: House Passes Measure to Repeal D.C. Noncitizen Voting Law
description: Fifty-two Democrats joined Republicans in favor of the legislation, which has little chance of enactment but offered the G.O.P. a chance to amplify Donald Trump’s false claims of widespread illegal voting by noncitizens.
content: The House passed legislation on Thursday that would undo a District of Columbia law allowing noncitizens to vote in local elections, part of a broader bid by Republicans to amplify false claims by former President Donald J. Trump of widespread illegal voting by immigrants, a rare occurrence that is already outlawed in federal elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis, Sara Curtis, Wendy Dorr and Daniel Powell
title: Miranda July Wrote a Perimenopause Novel
description: How writing “All Fours” helped her navigate middle age.
content: Our Styles editor, Marie Solis, talked with Miranda July about her new novel, “All Fours.” As July entered middle age, she looked around for a novel that could be a road map for her to navigate her own experience. She couldn’t find one. “This territory is so empty,” she told Solis. “Your options seem to be just sort of present like it’s not happening or maybe kind of go underground.” July spent four years writing the book she had been looking for. “All Fours” is out now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: Forget the Polls, President Biden. Our Readers Have Some Strategy Ideas.
description: Readers told us what they thought was missing from the president’s re-election campaign.
content: The results of the latest New York Times/Siena College polls showing Donald Trump leading President Biden in five crucial battleground states were bad news to many Democrats. There’s still time for Mr. Biden to win back some swing voters, but a lot of his supporters are wondering the same thing: How?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Biden Is Behind in the Polls
description: Readers discuss a column by Ezra Klein. Also: Benjamin Netanyahu’s fate; Madonna at 65; a pediatrics group on gender-affirming care.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Almeida
title: They’re Ignoring MrBeast’s Rules of YouTube, and Thriving
description: Many creators bend over backward to optimize videos for the algorithm, but some are experimenting with another concept: trusting their audience.
content: Late last year, Zackary Smigel, a YouTube creator, made a video titled “Why Is YouTube Like This?” By “this” he meant that the platform was filled with videos that have sensationalized titles, heavily edited content and grabby thumbnails, often featuring a person’s emotive face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Pragati K.B
title: Is Modi Worried? India’s Long-Deflated Opposition Finds Some Momentum.
description: After setting a very high bar for his party in the election, Prime Minister Narendra Modi often appears on the defensive as the voting nears its end.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi entered India’s general election projecting supreme confidence. “Ab ki baar, 400 paar” went his party’s slogan, meaning this time his side was gunning to surpass 400 seats in the lower house of Parliament, a staggering majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Plays Up His Putin Ties in Claiming He Could Get Gershkovich Released
description: A spokesman for the Kremlin said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has had no contact with former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed that, if re-elected, he could draw on his relationship with President Vladimir V. Putin to press Russia into releasing Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter who has been detained in a Moscow jail for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘The Garfield Movie’ Review: This Feels Like Too Much Effort
description: Garfield, voiced by Chris Pratt, is joined by Samuel L. Jackson as his father, in an inert big-screen adaptation that fundamentally misunderstands its protagonist.
content: Since Garfield’s debut in the 1970s, Jim Davis’s orange tabby has become one of the most successful brands to evolve from the humble American comic strip. And fortified by a reliable stream of cartoon shows, video games and a couple of bland Bill Murray-voiced films in the early 2000s, Garfield is now one of the more enduring images of the American imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Iran Buries President Raisi in His Hometown
description: The president, who died in a helicopter crash, was laid to rest at a holy shrine in the northeastern city of Mashhad.
content: Iran’s president was laid to rest in his hometown on Thursday, capping days of funeral observances after his death in a helicopter crash left the country without one of its highest-profile leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Tems, R&B’s Golden Child, Dials In
description: The Nigerian singer won a Grammy and worked for Beyoncé, Drake and Rihanna before making her first album. Now it’s time to be her own boss.
content: When the ground began to shake, rocking her bed to-and-fro like a raft in a current, Temilade Openiyi briefly wondered if she was dreaming. It was a bright April morning and she was still jet lagged from a flight — 12 hours from Lagos, Nigeria, to New York. It seemed unlikely that her hotel could actually be vibrating. And yet there she was, eyes wide open, bobbing along with everything else in the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Why Gardening Is So Good for You
description: Digging holes can be a workout and mood booster all rolled into one.
content: Last Saturday, I was covered in dirt, my back ached, the scream of a trillion cicadas rang in my ears, and, despite my best efforts, a sunburn was developing on the back of my neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Sara Cincurova
title: As Slovakia’s Prime Minister Remains Hospitalized, Politics Return to a Boil
description: Calls for unity after the shooting of Robert Fico last week have been largely ignored by the country’s politicians. Much of the tension has centered on a media law pushed by the government.
content: More than a week after being shot in an assassination attempt, Slovakia’s prime minister was still hospitalized in serious condition on Thursday, as calls for political unity after the attack have given way to a resurgence of hostility in the polarized Central European nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Justices Allowed a Contested Voting Map in South Carolina
description: Also, the U.S. called for the breakup of Ticketmaster’s owner. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority cleared the way today for South Carolina to keep using a congressional map that a lower court had deemed an unconstitutional racial gerrymander. All three liberal justices dissented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Pam Belluck
title: Louisiana Lawmakers Vote to Make Abortion Pills Controlled Substances
description: The legislation would make possession of the drugs without a prescription a crime in Louisiana, punishable with jail time.
content: Louisiana lawmakers passed legislation on Thursday to make the state the first in the nation to designate abortion pills as dangerous controlled substances. Possession of the drugs without a prescription would be a crime punishable with jail time and thousands of dollars in fines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,070, May 24, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and John Yoon
title: Stage Collapses at Campaign Rally in Mexico, Killing at Least 9
description: Strong wind caused the collapse in northern Mexico as a presidential hopeful campaigned for a local candidate, officials said. Dozens of people were injured.
content: A stage in northern Mexico where a presidential hopeful was campaigning for a local candidate collapsed after a gust of wind blew through on Wednesday night, leaving at least nine people dead and at least 70 others injured, a state governor said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Tennessee Attorney General to Review Company’s Bid to Sell Graceland
description: The attorney general’s office said it is looking into Nausanny Investments’ effort to foreclose on Elvis Presley’s former home. His heirs called it a fraud.
content: The attorney general of Tennessee, Jonathan Skrmetti, said Thursday that his office was looking into a private investment company’s attempt to foreclose on Graceland, Elvis Presley’s former home, after lawyers for Mr. Presley’s granddaughter sued to stop the proposed sale, accusing the company of fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: 5 Takeaways From the Latest Hearing on Campus Antisemitism
description: The leaders of Northwestern, Rutgers and the University of California, Los Angeles, appeared to have navigated their testimony before Congress without many significant missteps.
content: The leaders of three universities denied that their campuses have become “hotbeds of antisemitism,” as one House Republican described them in a congressional hearing on Thursday. But they acknowledged missteps in the handling of the pro-Palestinian demonstrations that have engulfed American universities in recent months, and said that some acts of hostility toward Jewish students need to be addressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Lapel Buttons
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: With Troubles at Home, Macron Pops Up 10,000 Miles Away
description: New Caledonia, a French territory in the Pacific, is on the brink of civil war as pro-independence activists protest a law that would expand voting rights.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France has a lot to manage. The European elections are fast approaching, and his party is predicted to lose. There are the frenzied preparations for the Olympic Games in Paris. A manhunt is underway for a convict whose brazen and deadly jailbreak shocked the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Virginia Foxx’s Focus on Antisemitism on College Campuses Has Raised Her Profile
description: The House member from North Carolina attributes her blunt conservative politics to her pulled-herself-up-by-her-bootstraps life.
content: Virginia Foxx has been a Republican congresswoman from North Carolina for almost 20 years. Over the last year, her campaign against antisemitism on college campuses, carried out as chairwoman of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, has raised her profile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Honors Kenya as the East African Nation Prepares to Send Forces to Haiti
description: President Biden welcomed President William Ruto of Kenya and said he intended to designate his country as a “major non-NATO ally.”
content: President Biden suggested on Thursday that the decision to have Kenya lead a security mission in Haiti, without troops from the United States on the ground, was meant to avoid the fraught history of American intervention in the deeply troubled country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
title: China Launches Military Drills Around Taiwan as ‘Punishment’
description: China said the sea and air drills were meant as a “stern warning” to its opponents after Taiwan’s new president asserted the island’s sovereignty in defiance of Beijing.
content: China launched two days of military drills surrounding Taiwan on Thursday in what it called a “strong punishment” to its opponents on the self-governing island, after Taiwan’s new president pledged to defend its sovereignty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Goldberg
title: Game Reviews: Mysteries of the Afterlife and the Eerie Present
description: In a strong month for indie games, Hauntii is a hunt for memories and Crow Country offers retro survival in a creepy amusement park. The origami-like Paper Trail feels a bit thin.
content: In a month rife with original indie games, including Animal Well and Lorelei and the Laser Eyes, there has seemingly been something for every player. The creativity continues with Hauntii, Crow Country and Paper Trail, even though one stumbles a bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Scudder
title: The Brewing Tradition Passed From Mother to Daughter
description: The beerlike beverage called suwe or tella is brewed in Eritrea and Ethiopia, as well as in diasporic communities like Dallas and Fort Worth.
content: The thick brown liquid had been fermenting in the jug for three days, which meant it was time for Fatean Gojela to get it ready to serve for Orthodox Easter. With her granddaughter, Ava, at her side, she poured it little by little through a thin mesh sack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Senate Democrats Open Inquiry Into Trump’s $1 Billion Request of Oil Industry
description: Two committees are seeking information from oil executives about a dinner where, the lawmakers say, the former president proposed a quid pro quo.
content: Senate Democrats opened an investigation on Thursday into former President Donald J. Trump’s meeting with oil and gas executives last month to determine whether Mr. Trump offered a “policies-for-money transaction” when he asked for $1 billion for his 2024 campaign so he could retake the White House and delete President Biden’s climate regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Fate of Retired Research Chimps Still in Limbo
description: The National Institutes of Health, which owns the chimps at the Alamogordo Primate Facility in New Mexico, has no plans to move the animals to sanctuary, despite a ruling from a federal judge.
content: It has been more than two decades since chimpanzee research came to a halt at the Alamogordo Primate Facility in New Mexico. And yet, some two dozen chimps still live there, despite a federal law that requires such retired research chimps to be moved to sanctuary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: At MoMA, LaToya Ruby Frazier Asks What Our Monuments Should Be
description: The documentary photographer honors those who turn their energies to a social good. And our critic says this artist does the same.
content: On an August night in 2017, a mob of neo-Nazi thugs under the banner “Unite the Right” gathered in a park in Charlottesville, Va., to protest the removal of a bronze statue of the Confederate general Robert E. Lee. Although Donald J. Trump, then the president, found no fault with the race-baiting demonstrators, other people did. A counterprotest ensued; the results were explosive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: The Full Guest List for Biden’s State Dinner With Kenya
description: The Bidens invited more than 450 guests, including Barack Obama, Bill and Hillary Clinton, Carol Moseley Braun, Melinda Gates, Lester Holt, LeVar Burton and Sean Penn.
content: The White House invited more than 450 guests to the state dinner hosted by President Biden for President William Ruto on Thursday night, including business executives, musicians, leaders of the United Nations, community organizers and scholars on sustainable development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The Biden Clean Energy Boom
description: The president’s signature 2022 climate law has sparked a rapid clean energy boom but its political impact is a lot less clear.
content: It’s been nearly two years since President Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act into law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Patrick McGeehan
title: Amtrak and N.J. Transit Service Resumes After Rush-Hour Meltdown
description: Service had been restored by late Wednesday night, but riders were warned Thursday morning to expect residual delays and cancellations.
content: After downed power cables completely halted rush-hour train service along the Northeast Corridor south of New York City on Wednesday night, New Jersey Transit and Amtrak service appeared to be nearly back to normal Thursday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Cannabis Tops Alcohol as Americans’ Daily Drug of Choice
description: A new study shows a growing number of people are regularly using cannabis, while frequent alcohol consumption has remained stable.
content: For the first time on record, cannabis has outpaced alcohol as the daily drug of choice for Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Defense Strategy in Gilgo Murder Case: Blame a Corrupt Police Chief
description: The lawyer for Rex Heuermann, the man accused in the case, said the early involvement of a notorious Long Island police chief may have tainted the investigation.
content: After Rex Heuermann was arrested last summer and then charged with murdering four women whose bodies were found in 2010 along Gilgo Beach on Long Island, prosecutors disclosed a barrage of details to support their case, including genetic evidence and sadistic porn sites they said Mr. Heuermann visited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: A Promise of ‘No Man Left Behind’ Leads to a Forest in England
description: A group led by archaeologists are searching for an American pilot who was killed when the B-17 he was flying crashed in eastern England in 1944.
content: The blackened site of the plane crash, overgrown with rhododendron bushes and hidden in the quiet woodlands of eastern England, had for 80 years been the final resting place of a missing American pilot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: 2024 Hurricane Season Is Expected to Be Abnormally Busy, NOAA Predicts
description: The Atlantic hurricane season is looking to be an extraordinary one, with 17 to 25 named storms predicted, experts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Joe Zucker, Prolific Painter of Innumerable Styles, Dies at 82
description: His art, which he described as “conceptual and literal,” used a variety of materials, including cotton, wood and even squeegee handles.
content: Joe Zucker, an influential painter who took his obsession with process and materials to unique extremes, died on May 15 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Political Consultant Who Orchestrated Fake Biden Robocalls Is Indicted
description: The calls used an artificial-intelligence impersonation of President Biden to urge Democrats not to vote in New Hampshire’s presidential primary.
content: Grand juries in four New Hampshire counties have indicted a Democratic consultant who admitted to orchestrating robocalls in January that used an artificial-intelligence impersonation of President Biden to urge Democrats not to vote in the state’s presidential primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: This Is the Life!
description: Wind your way through Adam Wagner’s puzzle.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Balint
title: Everyone Wants a Piece of Kafka, a Writer Who Refused to Be Claimed
description: A hundred years after Kafka’s death, people and nations are still fighting over his legacy.
content: In his novella “The Prague Orgy,” Philip Roth has a Czech writer say: “When I studied Kafka, the fate of his books in the hands of the Kafkologists seemed to me to be more grotesque than the fate of Josef K.” Just as Franz Kafka’s prose both demands and evades interpretation, something about his legacy has both solicited and resisted claims of ownership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Amit Elkayam
title: In a City of Ancient Jewish Mysticism, Israelis Arm for a Fight
description: In Safed, a center of kabbalah, ordinary citizens shocked by the Oct. 7 attacks are carrying military-grade weapons.
content: Eyal Ben-Ari tugged at the heavy assault rifle hanging over his shoulder as he tiptoed out of his pink house at sunrise, hoping not to wake his wife or six children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Very Delicious Vegetarian Eating
description: Hetty Lui McKinnon shares tips and recipes for eating more meatless meals, like cold noodle salad with spicy peanut sauce, and cumin mushroom and green beans stir fry.
content: If you’re a frequent reader of this newsletter (hi, Mom), you’re familiar with the name Hetty Lui McKinnon. I talk about Hetty’s recipes a lot — they’re delicious, of course, but also consistently satisfying, delivering a lot of wow and oomph (technical terms).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Foreign Interventions in Haiti: A Brief History
description: For decades, international soldiers have deployed to Haiti, sometimes leaving behind a troubled legacy.
content: Kenyan police officers are soon heading to Haiti with a daunting mission: help restore order to a country where killings and kidnappings are so rampant that hundreds of thousands of people have fled their homes and where, for years, it has been too dangerous to hold elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Ohio Elections Official Threatens to Exclude Biden From the Ballot
description: The Biden campaign is considering suing to ensure the president is on the ballot, after the Republican secretary of state said he would bar him over what is normally a minor procedural issue.
content: The Ohio General Assembly adjourned on Wednesday without addressing an issue that the state’s top elections official said would prevent President Biden from being placed on the ballot there, escalating a partisan clash that could result in the president not being on the ballot in all 50 states in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should Dogs Be Allowed Inside Restaurants and Stores?
description: Do you think there are types of businesses where dogs should be welcome? And places where dogs should not be permitted?
content: Do you ever see people bring dogs inside restaurants, stores or other businesses where you live? If you do, what is your reaction? Are you excited? Indifferent? Annoyed?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: There’s a Salad for That
description: Grilled halloumi and zucchini with salsa verde if you’re the cookout grill master, charred bok choy and cannellinis if you’re a salad-toting guest.
content: The unofficial kickoff of cookout season — Memorial Day weekend — hurtles toward us like an errant Frisbee in an overcrowded park. Will you meet it with rec-league reflexes and roll up to the party with a parade of complementary pasta salads, or will you let it ding you in the temple?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: A Test of Cloud-Brightening Machines Poses No Health Risk, Officials Say
description: After halting a test of controversial technology to fight global warming, the city of Alameda, Calif., said it had found no “measurable health risk” from the giant salty-mist-spraying fans.
content: A technology that could one day cool the planet cleared a key hurdle on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Bookseller Who Brought Hardcovers to America’s Most Famous Bookstore
description: In “Reading the Room,” Paul Yamazaki, the chief buyer for City Lights Booksellers, calls this “one of the richest and most rewarding times” to be a literature fan.
content: What makes you good at your job?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Sight’ Review: An Eye Doctor’s (Inner) Journey From China
description: Based on the real life of the pioneering ophthalmologist Ming Wang, this movie follows the character’s struggle to see inside himself.
content: Ming Wang, the real-life physician whose biography is the basis for this fictional feature, is a Nashville-based ophthalmologist whose degree in laser physics has presumably been a boon in his work restoring sight to visually impaired patients, many of whom are children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Restaurant Collapse Kills at Least 4 and Injures 16 in Majorca
description: People were feared to be trapped after parts of a beach restaurant’s terraces fell down to ground level on a Spanish island popular with tourists.
content: A beachfront restaurant on the Spanish island of Majorca partly collapsed on Thursday, killing at least four people and injuring 16, officials said, with others feared trapped in the wreckage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Here’s What to Know About Canada’s Wildfire Season
description: Despite a relatively wet spring, government officials are warning that persistent drought across Western Canada could leave the region vulnerable to major fires.
content: Last year in Canada, a total of 7,100 fires burned in locations that stretched from one end of the country to the other. An entire city south of the Arctic Circle had to evacuate. Smoke from the blazes drifted down and darkened the skies of major American cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Once Critics of Trump, These Republicans Are Now Playing by His Rules
description: Republicans like Nikki Haley have had to contort themselves to overlook their criticisms of former President Donald J. Trump as they decide to back him after all.
content: There was a time when Nikki Haley thought an “unstable and unhinged” person should not be president. But that was February. Now she says she will vote for Donald J. Trump — just three months after warning that he would be “an unsafe president.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Queen of the Deuce’ Review: A Mother of Invention
description: This warm remembrance of a Times Square legend is too careful with its iconoclastic heroine.
content: “Queen of the Deuce,” a curiously flat recounting of the life and titillating times of the adult-theater entrepreneur Chelly Wilson, offers a sadly conventional profile of one of the most vividly eccentric characters in the history of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Their Diplomas Came With Envelopes of Cash, and a Catch
description: The billionaire Rob Hale gave the 1,200 graduates of the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth a gift, and asked them to give, too.
content: Until the final minutes of their commencement ceremony last Thursday, the 1,200 graduates of the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth thought they knew what they would remember most about it: the supremely bad weather during the outdoor ceremony, where they sat drenched and shivering in a torrential rainstorm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyon
title: Bridesmaids, Bubbly and Botox
description: For some, undergoing a cosmetic procedure or two is an essential component of wedding prep.
content: Danielle McNamara had often thought about getting a nose job. But it wasn’t until she was reviewing photos from her proposal in July 2021 that she began to seriously consider scheduling a surgery. Ms. McNamara, 36, of Vancouver, Wash., knew that she wanted to be able to look at images from her wedding and “not be like, ‘Gosh, I wish I would’ve done that or done that sooner.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Did Cate Blanchett Make a Pro-Palestinian Fashion Statement at Cannes?
description: The actress hasn’t said so, but some internet users think she did. Plus, a bleak week for small fashion brands and wedding dresses for fashion-forward brides.
content: Since the start of the Israel-Hamas war, followers of events known for being fashion spectacles — the Oscars, the Met Gala, Eurovision — have watched them become venues for making sartorial as well as political statements about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Ari Emanuel Condemns Netanyahu, Drawing Boos at Jewish Group’s Gala
description: “For the good of Israel, he should go,” Emanuel, chief executive of the media group Endeavor, said of Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s conservative prime minister.
content: While accepting an award from a major Jewish group on Wednesday night, the media executive Ari Emanuel condemned Israel’s conservative prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, for his leadership since the Hamas attack of Oct. 7, a conspicuous statement from one of Hollywood’s most powerful figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Billie Eilish and Taylor Swift Race for No. 1
description: The two pop music titans, locked in a close contest for the top of next week’s album chart, are stoking fans’ competitive spirit with a variety of digital tactics.
content: A cold war between pop music titans — or at least their mobilizing fan bases and record labels — turned into a digital arms race this week as both Taylor Swift and Billie Eilish gunned for the No. 1 spot on next week’s Billboard album chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phillip Maciak
title: The One Thing That Can Save Cinema From C.G.I. Oblivion
description: The motion-capture acting in “The Planet of the Apes” movies tries to preserve the magic of the physical world amid all the effects in a big budget franchise.
content: He’s a goofy little ape in a puffer vest, and he’s giving us a thumbs-up. This was just a small moment of levity in an otherwise grim and operatic film, the 2017 epic “War for the Planet of the Apes.” But it stuck with me. In the midst of a dire war for the fate of humanity, we watch this misfit creature amble into the frame, dwarfed by a magisterial orangutan on one side and the stately ape revolutionary Caesar on the other, both preparing for battle. He turns to Caesar for approval, waits for an awkward beat and flashes his thumbs-up. I cannot overstate how charming it is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: As Trump Campaigns in New York, Biden Points Black Voters to His Rival’s Past
description: Ahead of Donald Trump’s political event in the Bronx, the Biden campaign released a television ad highlighting Mr. Trump’s treatment of Black people.
content: President Biden’s campaign on Thursday released a new advertisement aimed at Black voters. It comes as former President Donald J. author: By Sophie Pinkham
title: A Giant Crater in Siberia Is Belching Up Russia’s Past
description: A yawning hole in the Siberian landscape should be a warning about the dangers of extraction.
content: As the world warms, permafrost is thawing across two-thirds of Russia, threatening cities and towns that were constructed to house miners sent to dig up a subterranean trove of oil, gas, gold and diamonds. Even the roads are buckling, cracking and collapsing, as if in a slow-motion earthquake. And outside a small town called Batagay, deep in the Siberian hinterland, a crater is rapidly opening up — known to local residents as the gateway to the underworld.
source.name: The New York Times

content: The glittering “Solo” centers on Simon (Théodore Pellerin), a charming 20-something making a name for himself as a drag queen in Montreal. Simon’s life is glamorous and filled with loving support from the other performers who work at his nightclub; and from his family, particularly his older sister, Maude (Alice Moreault), his confidante and a costume designer who makes dresses for Simon’s drag alter ego, the blonde bombshell Glory Gore.

author: By David Brooks
title: We Haven’t Hit Peak Populism Yet
description: Americans have traded their faith in the American dream for the same sour, populist mood as pretty much everybody else.
content: We used to have long debates about American exceptionalism, about whether this country was an outlier among nations, and I always thought the bulk of the evidence suggested that it was. But these days our political attitudes are pretty ordinary. America, far from standing out as the champion of democracy, as a nation that welcomes immigrants, as a perpetually youthful nation energized by its faith in the American dream, is now caught in the same sour, populist mood as pretty much everywhere else.
